name: Apple___Apple_scab
cause: Fungus Venturia inaequalis. Favorable conditions are cool, wet weather.
cure: Use fungicides and resistant apple varieties. Prune and destroy infected leaves.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that creates dark, scabby spots on apple leaves and fruits. It spreads easily in wet, cool weather.
how_to_spot: Look for dark brown or olive-green spots on leaves. Fruits may have raised, corky spots. Leaves might curl and fall early.
prevention_tips: Remove fallen leaves in autumn. Space plants well for air flow. Water plants at base, not from above. Apply preventive spray before rains.

name: Apple___Black_rot
cause: Caused by the fungus Botryosphaeria obtusa.
cure: Prune and remove infected areas. Apply fungicides during the growing season.
simple_explanation: A fungal infection that causes fruits to rot and turn black. It can also damage leaves and branches.
how_to_spot: Fruits develop brown spots that turn into soft, black rotten areas. Leaves show purple-bordered spots. Dead branches may appear.
prevention_tips: Cut and burn infected branches immediately. Remove mummified fruits from tree. Keep orchard clean. Avoid injuries to tree bark.

name: Apple___Cedar_apple_rust
cause: Fungus Gymnosporangium juniperi-virginianae. Requires junipers as an alternate host.
cure: Remove nearby juniper hosts. Use resistant varieties and fungicides.
simple_explanation: A disease that needs both apple and juniper trees to spread. Creates bright orange or yellow spots on leaves.
how_to_spot: Yellow-orange spots appear on upper leaf surface in spring. Small black dots may form in centers of spots. Fruits can also develop spots.
prevention_tips: Remove nearby juniper bushes if possible. Choose disease-resistant apple varieties. Apply fungicide in early spring.

name: Apple___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your apple plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and vibrant. No spots, discoloration, or wilting. Normal growth pattern.
prevention_tips: Continue regular watering and fertilizing. Prune dead branches. Monitor regularly for any changes. Maintain good spacing between plants.

name: Background_without_leaves
cure: Not applicable.
simple_explanation: No plant leaf was detected in the image. Please take a clearer photo of the affected leaf.
how_to_spot: Image shows background, soil, or unclear plant parts instead of a clear leaf view.
prevention_tips: Take photos in good lighting. Focus on a single leaf. Fill 60-80% of frame with the leaf. Avoid shadows and blur.

name: Blueberry___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your blueberry plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and vibrant. No spots, discoloration, or wilting. Normal growth and fruit development.
prevention_tips: Maintain acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5). Water regularly, especially during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Prune old branches annually.

name: Cherry___Powdery_mildew
cure: Apply sulfur-based or fungicide treatments. Ensure good air circulation.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that creates a white, powdery coating on leaves and fruits. Looks like flour was sprinkled on the plant.
how_to_spot: White powdery patches appear on leaves, shoots, and fruits. Leaves may curl, twist, or become distorted. Growth may slow down.
prevention_tips: Plant in sunny, well-ventilated areas. Avoid overhead watering. Remove infected leaves quickly. Space plants properly for airflow.

name: Cherry___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your cherry plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are bright green with no spots. Branches look strong and healthy. Normal flowering and fruiting pattern.
prevention_tips: Prune after harvest to maintain shape. Water deeply but infrequently. Protect from birds during fruiting. Monitor for pests regularly.

name: Corn___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray_leaf_spot
cure: Use resistant hybrids and fungicide sprays.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that creates gray or brown rectangular spots on corn leaves. Can reduce crop yield significantly.
how_to_spot: Long, rectangular gray or brown spots appear between leaf veins. Spots may have yellow edges. Lower leaves are affected first.
prevention_tips: Rotate crops yearly - don't plant corn in same field. Remove old crop debris. Plant resistant varieties. Ensure proper spacing.

name: Corn___Common_rust
cure: Apply fungicides and plant resistant varieties.
simple_explanation: A disease that creates rusty-colored bumps on corn leaves. Spreads quickly in cool, humid weather.
how_to_spot: Small, circular or oval rust-colored pustules on both sides of leaves. Pustules release rusty powder when rubbed. Leaves turn yellow.
prevention_tips: Plant early-maturing varieties. Use resistant hybrid seeds. Apply fungicide if disease is severe. Monitor weather conditions.

name: Corn___Northern_Leaf_Blight
cure: Use resistant varieties and fungicides.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that creates long, cigar-shaped spots on corn leaves. Can cause serious yield loss in wet conditions.
how_to_spot: Long, elliptical gray-green spots that turn tan. Spots can be 1-6 inches long. Entire leaves may die. Starts on lower leaves first.
prevention_tips: Choose resistant corn hybrids. Bury crop residue after harvest. Rotate with non-host crops. Plant early to avoid peak disease period.

name: Corn___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your corn plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and upright. No spots or discoloration. Stalks are strong. Good tassel and ear development.
prevention_tips: Maintain proper plant spacing. Provide adequate water, especially during tasseling. Apply balanced fertilizer. Control weeds early.

name: Grape___Black_rot
cure: Prune infected areas and apply fungicides.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that turns grapes into hard, black, shriveled 'mummies'. Also affects leaves and shoots.
how_to_spot: Small tan spots on leaves that enlarge and turn brown. Grapes develop brown circles, then shrivel into black mummies. Young shoots have dark lesions.
prevention_tips: Remove all mummified grapes from vines and ground. Prune for better air circulation. Apply fungicide before bloom and after rain.

name: Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles)
cure: Remove infected wood. Avoid injuries to vines.
simple_explanation: A serious trunk disease that weakens grapevines over time. Causes leaves to show a 'tiger-stripe' pattern and fruits to shrivel.
how_to_spot: Leaves show yellow stripes between veins (tiger-stripe pattern). Dark streaks inside wood when cut. Grapes may have dark spots and shrivel. Sudden vine collapse possible.
prevention_tips: Prevent pruning wounds during wet weather. Use clean, sanitized pruning tools. Avoid large cuts. Remove severely infected vines completely.

name: Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_Leaf_Spot)
cure: Apply fungicides and manage vineyard hygiene.
simple_explanation: A leaf disease that creates brown spots surrounded by yellow halos. Can cause early leaf drop and weaken the vine.
how_to_spot: Circular brown spots with yellow halos on leaves. Spots may merge and form large brown patches. Leaves turn yellow and fall early.
prevention_tips: Remove fallen leaves from vineyard. Ensure good air circulation through proper pruning. Apply preventive fungicide during wet periods.

name: Grape___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your grapevine is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and fully developed. No spots, stripes, or discoloration. Grapes developing normally. Good vine vigor.
prevention_tips: Prune annually for air circulation. Train vines on proper support system. Water at base, not overhead. Monitor regularly during growing season.

name: Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening)
cause: Bacterium Candidatus Liberibacter spp. Spread by psyllid insects.
cure: Control psyllid population and remove infected trees.
simple_explanation: A very serious bacterial disease spread by tiny insects. Makes fruits turn green and bitter. Eventually kills the tree.
how_to_spot: Leaves show yellow blotches (not symmetrical). Fruits stay partially green, taste bitter. Fruits may be lopsided. Tree shows stunted growth and twig dieback.
prevention_tips: Control psyllid insects with approved pesticides. Use disease-free nursery plants. Remove infected trees immediately to protect others. Monitor trees weekly.

name: Peach___Bacterial_spot
cure: Use resistant varieties and copper-based bactericides.
simple_explanation: A bacterial infection that creates dark spots on leaves and fruits. Can cause severe fruit damage and leaf drop.
how_to_spot: Small, dark purple to black spots on leaves. Spots may have yellow halos. Fruits develop brown, sunken spots. Leaves may have holes where spots fell out.
prevention_tips: Plant resistant varieties. Avoid overhead irrigation. Apply copper spray during dormant season. Don't work in orchard when plants are wet.

name: Peach___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your peach tree is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green with no spots. Fruits developing with good color. No gummosis (sap oozing). Good growth and branching.
prevention_tips: Prune in late winter for shape and airflow. Thin fruits for better size and quality. Water deeply but infrequently. Fertilize in early spring.

name: Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot
cure: Use copper-based bactericides and resistant varieties.
simple_explanation: A bacterial disease that creates dark, greasy-looking spots on pepper leaves and fruits. Spreads quickly in warm, wet weather.
how_to_spot: Small, dark green water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown. Fruits develop raised brown spots with white halos. Leaves may turn yellow and drop.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seeds. Avoid overhead watering. Don't touch plants when wet. Rotate crops - don't plant peppers in same spot yearly.

name: Pepper,_bell___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your pepper plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are dark green and glossy. No spots or wilting. Flowers forming normally. Fruits developing with good color and shape.
prevention_tips: Water at soil level, not on leaves. Stake plants for support. Remove weeds regularly. Harvest fruits when fully developed to encourage more production.

name: Potato___Early_blight
cure: Apply fungicides and practice crop rotation.
simple_explanation: A common fungal disease that creates brown spots with rings on leaves, like a target or bull's-eye. Can reduce potato yield.
how_to_spot: Brown spots with concentric rings (target pattern) on older leaves. Leaves turn yellow around spots. Dark, sunken spots may appear on tubers.
prevention_tips: Rotate potatoes with non-related crops. Remove volunteer potato plants. Water at base, not overhead. Hill soil around stems to protect tubers.

name: Potato___Late_blight
cure: Use resistant varieties and fungicides.
simple_explanation: A very serious disease that can destroy entire potato crop quickly. Famous for causing the Irish Potato Famine. Spreads fast in cool, wet weather.
how_to_spot: Water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown-black. White fuzzy growth on leaf undersides. Stems may have dark streaks. Tubers develop brown, corky rot.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seed potatoes. Plant resistant varieties. Apply preventive fungicide before symptoms appear. Destroy infected plants immediately.

name: Potato___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your potato plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are vibrant green. No spots, wilting, or yellowing. Strong stems and good growth. Plants standing upright.
prevention_tips: Hill soil around plants as they grow. Water consistently, especially during tuber formation. Monitor for Colorado potato beetles. Harvest when tops die back.

name: Raspberry___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your raspberry plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green with no spots. Canes are firm and upright. Good fruit production. No wilting or dieback.
prevention_tips: Remove old fruiting canes after harvest. Thin new canes for better air circulation. Mulch around plants. Provide support with stakes or wires.

name: Soybean___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your soybean plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and trifoliate (three leaflets). No spots or yellowing. Good pod development. Plants standing well.
prevention_tips: Rotate with corn or wheat. Use certified seeds. Maintain proper plant spacing. Control weeds early. Monitor for insect pests.

name: Squash___Powdery_mildew
cure: Apply sulfur-based fungicides and maintain good air circulation.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that covers leaves with white powdery coating, like they've been dusted with flour. Common in warm, dry days and cool nights.
how_to_spot: White powdery spots on upper leaf surfaces. Spots merge to cover entire leaf. Leaves may yellow, curl, and die. Fruits may not develop properly.
prevention_tips: Space plants well for air flow. Water at soil level in morning. Remove infected leaves promptly. Spray milk solution (1:10 milk to water) weekly.

name: Strawberry___Leaf_scorch
cure: Remove infected leaves and apply fungicides.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that makes strawberry leaves look scorched or burned. Can weaken plants and reduce fruit production.
how_to_spot: Irregular purple to brown spots on leaves. Spots may have gray centers. Severely infected leaves look scorched and die. Older leaves affected first.
prevention_tips: Remove old leaves after harvest. Use drip irrigation instead of sprinklers. Plant resistant varieties. Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash.

name: Strawberry___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your strawberry plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are green and bright. No spots or discoloration. Flowers blooming well. Fruits developing with good color.
prevention_tips: Mulch with straw to keep fruits clean. Remove runners if not needed. Water regularly, especially during fruiting. Fertilize after harvest.

name: Tomato___Bacterial_spot
cure: Apply copper-based bactericides and practice crop rotation.
simple_explanation: A bacterial disease that creates small, dark spots on tomato leaves and fruits. Spreads rapidly through water splash and handling.
how_to_spot: Small, dark brown to black spots on leaves with yellow halos. Fruits develop raised brown spots. Leaves may turn yellow and fall. Spots feel rough.
prevention_tips: Use disease-free seeds and transplants. Avoid working with plants when wet. Water at soil level only. Rotate tomatoes with non-related crops yearly.

name: Tomato___Early_blight
cure: Apply fungicides and remove infected leaves.
simple_explanation: A common fungal disease that creates brown spots with ring patterns on older leaves. Can spread to fruits and reduce yield.
how_to_spot: Brown spots with concentric circles (like a target) on lower, older leaves first. Leaves yellow around spots and fall off. Dark sunken spots on fruits near stem.
prevention_tips: Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash. Remove lower leaves that touch ground. Water at base in morning. Space plants for good air flow.

name: Tomato___Late_blight
cure: Use resistant varieties and fungicides.
simple_explanation: A devastating disease that can kill entire tomato plants in days. Same disease that caused Irish Potato Famine. Loves cool, wet weather.
how_to_spot: Gray-green water-soaked spots on leaves that turn brown-black quickly. White fuzzy mold on leaf undersides. Stems have dark streaks. Fruits develop greasy brown rot.
prevention_tips: Plant resistant varieties when possible. Apply preventive fungicide before rain. Remove infected plants immediately. Don't plant near potatoes.

name: Tomato___Leaf_Mold
cure: Apply fungicides and ensure good ventilation.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease common in greenhouses and humid areas. Creates yellow spots on top of leaves and fuzzy mold underneath.
how_to_spot: Pale green or yellow spots on upper leaf surface. Olive-gray to brown fuzzy mold on leaf undersides. Older leaves affected first. No fruit spots usually.
prevention_tips: Improve air circulation - use fans in greenhouses. Don't overcrowd plants. Water in morning. Keep humidity below 85%. Remove infected leaves promptly.

name: Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot
cure: Remove infected leaves and apply fungicides.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that creates many small spots with dark borders on leaves. Can cause severe leaf loss if not controlled.
how_to_spot: Numerous small, circular spots with gray centers and dark brown borders. Tiny black dots (spores) visible in spot centers. Lower leaves affected first.
prevention_tips: Mulch heavily to prevent soil splash. Remove infected leaves immediately. Stake or cage plants off ground. Avoid overhead watering after transplanting.

name: Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider_mite
cure: Use miticides or insecticidal soaps.
simple_explanation: Tiny spider-like pests (almost invisible) that suck plant juices. Create fine webbing on leaves. Thrive in hot, dry conditions.
how_to_spot: Tiny yellow or white speckles on leaves. Fine webbing on undersides of leaves. Leaves turn bronze, curl, and drop. Mites look like moving dots.
prevention_tips: Spray plants with strong water stream regularly. Keep plants well-watered - mites love drought stress. Introduce predatory mites. Avoid dusty conditions.

name: Tomato___Target_Spot
cure: Apply fungicides and ensure good air circulation.
simple_explanation: A fungal disease that makes brown spots with target-like rings on leaves. Similar to early blight but spots are more circular.
how_to_spot: Brown circular spots with concentric rings on leaves. Spots have yellow halos. Affects leaves at all levels (not just bottom). Fruits may have dark sunken spots.
prevention_tips: Space plants well apart. Remove lower leaves to improve airflow. Apply mulch to reduce soil splash. Rotate crops yearly. Water in early morning.

name: Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus
cure: Control whitefly population and use resistant varieties.
simple_explanation: A viral disease spread by tiny whitefly insects. Makes leaves curl upward, turn yellow, and stops fruit production. Cannot be cured.
how_to_spot: Leaves curl upward and edges roll inward. Leaves turn yellow progressively. Plant becomes stunted and bushy. Flowers drop. Few or no fruits form.
prevention_tips: Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies. Cover young plants with fine mesh. Plant resistant varieties. Remove infected plants immediately. Control weeds.

name: Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus
cause: Virus transmitted through contact and contaminated tools.
cure: Remove infected plants and sterilize tools.
simple_explanation: A highly contagious virus that creates mottled, mosaic-like patterns on leaves. Spreads through touch, tools, and even cigarette smoke.
how_to_spot: Light and dark green mottled pattern on leaves. Leaves may be distorted or fern-like. Fruits show yellow blotches and brown streaks inside. Stunted growth.
prevention_tips: Wash hands before working with plants. Sterilize tools with bleach solution. Don't smoke near tomatoes. Use resistant varieties. Remove infected plants in plastic bag.

name: Tomato___healthy
cure: Maintain good cultural practices for optimal health.
simple_explanation: Your tomato plant is healthy! No disease detected.
how_to_spot: Leaves are vibrant green with no spots. Strong stems. Good flower clusters. Fruits developing normally with good color.
prevention_tips: Stake or cage for support. Prune suckers for better air flow. Water deeply 1-2 times weekly. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks. Harvest ripe fruits promptly.
